case_vignette:
A 70-year-old female with past medical history of end stage renal disease on hemodialysis, coronary artery disease presents to dermatology clinic complaining of a painful rash on the right leg present for several weeks and enlargening. She admits she often misses hemodialysis sessions. Examination of the right lower leg demonstrates a retiform violaceous plaque with large black eschar. A punch biopsy reveals calcification of small and medium sized vessels with thrombosis.  The patient is diagnosed with calciphylaxis, a rare and serious condition that is often associated with end stage renal disease. The patient is advised to attend all hemodialysis sessions and to avoid any further trauma to the affected area. The patient is also advised to have a vascular surgeon evaluate the affected area for possible surgical intervention.

A punch biopsy reveals calcification of small and medium sized vessels with thrombosis.  The patient is diagnosed with calciphylaxis, a rare and serious condition that is often associated with end stage renal disease. The patient is advised to attend all hemodialysis sessions and to avoid any further trauma to the affected area. The patient is also advised to have a vascular surgeon evaluate the affected area for possible surgical intervention.

In general, it's a good idea to use inclusive language in medical writing, as it helps
